14. Equation: Abstract coupled equations¶

class optcom.equations.abstract_coupled_equation.AbstractCoupledEquation(nbr_eqs)¶

Parent class of any coupled equation.

Notes

Considering \(l = 1, \ldots, M\) equations with \(j = 1, \ldots, K_l\) channels per equation, the AbstractCoupledEquation class implement the following generic equations:

\[\frac{\partial A_{lj}}{\partial z} = f_l(\{A_{l1}, \ldots, A_{lK_l}\}) + \sum_{m \neq l}^{M} \hat{E}_{lm}^{l} A_{lj} + \sum_{m \neq l}^{M} \hat{E}_{lm}^{n} A_{lj} + \sum_{m=0}^M \hat{E}_{lm}^{a} \sum_{k=0}^{K_m} A_{mk}\]

where \(f_l\) is an equation related to equation \(l\), \(\hat{E}^l\) are the linear effects (self._effects_lin), \(\hat{E}^n\) are the non linear effects (self._effects_non_lin), and \(\hat{E}^l\) are the general effects (self._effects_all).

close(domain, *fields)¶

This function is called once after a Stepper ended the computation.

Return type

None

open(domain, *fields)¶

This function is called once before a Stepper began the computation. Pass the time, wavelength and center wavelength to all the effects in the equation.

Return type

None

set(waves, h, x)¶

This function is called before each step of the computation.

Return type

None

update(waves, h, x)¶

This function is called after each step of the computation.

Return type

None

17. Equation: Abstract non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.abstract_nlse.AbstractNLSE(alpha, alpha_order, beta, beta_order, gamma, core_radius, NA, ATT, DISP, medium)¶

Non linear Schrodinger equations.

Represent the different effects in the NLSE as well as different types of NLSEs.

Parameters

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • core_radius (float) -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • NA (Union[float, Callable]) -- The numerical aperture.

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber.

This function is called once after a Stepper ended the computation.

Return type

None

This function is called once before a Stepper began the computation. Pass the time, wavelength and center wavelength to all the effects in the equation.

Return type

None

This function is called before each step of the computation.

18. Equation: Approximated non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.anlse.ANLSE(alpha=None, alpha_order=1, beta=None, beta_order=2, gamma=None, sigma=2.0, eta=2.0, T_R=0.003, core_radius=5.0, NA=0.1, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, SS=False, RS=False, approx_type=1, medium='sio2')¶

Approximated non linear Schrodinger equations.

Represent the different effects in the approximated NLSE.

Notes

NLSE approximation 1:

\[\frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + i S \frac{1}{A_j} \bigg(\frac{\partial |A_j|^2 A_j}{\partial t} + \eta \sum_{k\neq j} \frac{\partial |A_k|^2 A_j}{\partial t} \bigg) - T_R \bigg(\frac{\partial |A_j|^2}{\partial t} + \eta \sum_{k\neq j} \frac{\partial |A_k|^2}{\partial t} \bigg) \Bigg] A_j\]

NLSE approximation 2:

\[\frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + i S \bigg(A^{*}_j + \frac{\eta}{A_j} \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2\bigg) \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} + \big(i S - T_R\big) \frac{\partial |A_j|^2}{\partial t} + \eta \big(i S - T_R\big) \sum_{k\neq j} \frac{\partial |A_k|^2}{\partial t} \Bigg] A_j\]

NLSE approximation 3:

\[\frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + \bigg((2 i S - T_R) A^{*}_j + i S \frac{\eta}{A_j} \sum_{k\neq j} |A_k|^2\bigg) \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} + \big(i S - T_R\big) A_j \frac{\partial A^{*}_j}{\partial t} + \eta \big(i S - T_R\big) \sum_{k\neq j} \frac{\partial |A_k|^2}{\partial t} \Bigg] A_j\]

NLSE approximation 1:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \hat{N}(A_j) = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + i S \frac{1}{A_j} \mathcal{F}^{-1}\bigg\{ (-i \omega) \mathcal{F}\Big\{|A_j|^2 A_j + \eta \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 A_j\Big\}\bigg\} \\ \quad\quad\quad - T_R \mathcal{F}^{-1}\bigg\{(-i\omega) \mathcal{F}\Big\{|A_j|^2+ \eta \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 \Big\}\bigg\} \Bigg] \end{split}\end{split}\]

NLSE approximation 2:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \hat{N}(A_j) = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma\sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + i S \Big(A_j^* + \eta \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2\Big) \mathcal{F}^{-1}\big\{ (-i \omega) \mathcal{F}\{A_j\}\big\}\\ \quad\quad\quad + \big(i S - T_R\big)\mathcal{F}^{-1}\bigg\{(-i\omega) \mathcal{F}\Big\{|A_j|^2 + \eta \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2\Big\}\bigg\} \Bigg] \end{split}\end{split}\]

NLSE approximation 3:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \hat{N}(A_j) = i\gamma \Bigg[ |A_j|^2 + \sigma\sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2 + \bigg((2 i S - T_R) A_j^* + i\eta S \sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2\bigg) \mathcal{F}^{-1}\big\{ (- i \omega) \mathcal{F}\{A_j\}\big\} \\ \quad\quad\quad + \big(i S - T_R\big) A_j \mathcal{F}^{-1}\big\{(-i\omega)\mathcal{F}\{A_j^*\}\big\} + \eta\big(i S - T_R\big) \mathcal{F}^{-1}\bigg\{ (- i \omega) \mathcal{F}\Big\{\sum_{k\neq j}|A_k|^2\Big\}\bigg\}\Bigg] \end{split}\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma (float) -- Positive term multiplying the XPM term of the NLSE

  • eta (float) -- Positive term multiplying the XPM in other non linear terms of the NLSE

  • T_R (float) -- The raman coefficient. \([]\)

  • core_radius (float) -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • NA (Union[float, Callable]) -- The numerical aperture.

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM (bool) -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • SS (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-steepening.

  • RS (bool) -- If True, trigger the Raman scattering.

  • approx_type (int) -- The type of the NLSE approximation.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber.

op_non_lin(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

Represent the non linear effects of the approximated NLSE.

Return type

Array

19. Equation: Non-linear Schrodinger equations¶

class optcom.equations.nlse.NLSE(alpha=None, alpha_order=1, beta=None, beta_order=2, gamma=None, sigma=2.0, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, f_R=0.245, core_radius=5.0, NA=0.1, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, medium='sio2')¶

Non linear Schrodinger equations.

Represent the different effects in the NLSE.

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} &= i\gamma \Bigg[\bigg[(1-f_R)|A_j(z,t)|^2 + f_R\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}h_R(s)|A_j(z,t-s)|^2 ds \bigg] \\ &\quad + \sum_{k\neq j} \bigg[\sigma (1-f_R)|A_k(z,t)|^2 + \eta f_R\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}h_R(s)|A_k(z,t-s)|^2 ds\bigg] \Bigg] A_j \end{split}\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma (float) -- Positive term multiplying the XPM term of the NLSE

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • f_R (float) -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • core_radius (float) -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • NA (Union[float, Callable]) -- The numerical aperture.

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM (bool) -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber.

op_non_lin(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

Represent the non linear effects of the approximated NLSE.

Parameters

  • waves (Array) -- The wave packet propagating in the fiber.

  • id (int) -- The ID of the considered wave in the wave packet.

  • corr_wave (Optional[Array]) -- Correction wave, use for consistency.

Return type

Array

Returns

The non linear term for the considered wave

Notes

\[\hat{N} = i \gamma \Big[ (1-f_R) |A|^2 + f_R \mathcal{F}^{-1} \big\{\mathcal{F}\{h_R\}\mathcal{F}\{|A|^2\} \big\}\Big]\]

20. Equation: General non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.gnlse.GNLSE(alpha=None, alpha_order=1, beta=None, beta_order=2, gamma=None, sigma=2.0, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, f_R=0.245, core_radius=5.0, NA=0.1, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, medium='sio2')¶

General non linear Schrodinger equations.

Represent the different effects in the GNLSE.

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial t} &= i\gamma \Big(1+\frac{i}{\omega_0} \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\Big) \Bigg[\bigg[(1-f_R)|A_j(z,t)|^2 + f_R\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}h_R(s)|A_j(z,t-s)|^2 ds \bigg] \\ &\quad + \sum_{k\neq j} \bigg[\sigma (1-f_R)|A_k(z,t)|^2 + \eta f_R\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}h_R(s)|A_k(z,t-s)|^2 ds\bigg] \Bigg] A_j \end{split}\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma (float) -- Positive term multiplying the XPM term of the NLSE

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • f_R (float) -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • core_radius (float) -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • NA (Union[float, Callable]) -- The numerical aperture.

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM (bool) -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber.

Represent the non linear effects of the approximated NLSE.

21. Equation: Abstract amplifier non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.abstract_ampnlse.AbstractAmpNLSE(re, alpha, alpha_order, beta, beta_order, gamma, gain_order, R_0, R_L, nl_index, ATT, DISP, GS, medium, dopant)¶
Parameters

  • re (REFiber) -- A fiber rate equation object.

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • gain_order (int) -- The order of the gain coefficients to take into account. (from the Rate Equations resolution)

  • R_0 (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber start.

  • R_L (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber end.

  • nl_index (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear index. Used to calculate the non linear parameter. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\)

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • GS (bool) -- If True, trigger the gain saturation.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber amplifier.

  • dopant (str) -- The doped medium of the fiber amplifier.

class RefractiveIndex(re, step)¶

Container for refractive index computation.

Parameters

medium -- The medium in which the wave propagates.

n(omega)¶

Compute the refractive index.

Parameters

omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

Returns

The refractive index.

initial_condition(waves, end)¶
Parameters

  • waves (Array) -- The propagationg waves.

  • end (bool) -- If true, boundary counditions at z=L, else at z=0.

Return type

Array

Returns

The waves after initial conditions.

Notes

If co-propagating signal and pump:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} A_s^+(z=0) &= \sqrt{R_0} A_s^-(z=0) + P_{s,ref}^+(z=0)\\ A_p^+(z=0) &= \sqrt{R_0} A_p^-(z=0) + P_{p, ref}^+(z=0)\\ A_s^-(z=L) &= \sqrt{R_L} A_s^+(z=L)\\ A_p^-(z=L) &= \sqrt{R_L} A_s^+(z=L) \end{split}\end{split}\]

If counter-propagating signal and pump:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} A_s^+(z=0) &= \sqrt{R_0} A_s^-(z=0) + P_{s,ref}^+(z=0)\\ A_p^+(z=0) &= \sqrt{R_0} A_p^-(z=0)\\ A_s^-(z=L) &= \sqrt{R_L} A_s^+(z=L)\\ A_p^-(z=L) &= \sqrt{R_L} A_s^+(z=L) + P_{p, ref}^-(z=0) \end{split}\end{split}\]

23. Equation: Amplifier non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.ampnlse.AmpNLSE(re_eq, alpha=None, alpha_order=1, beta=None, beta_order=2, gamma=None, gain_order=1, sigma=2.0, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, f_R=0.245, R_0=0.0008, R_L=0.0008, nl_index=None, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, GS=True, medium='sio2', dopant='yt')¶

Non linear Schrodinger equations for fiber amplifier.

Represent the different effects in the NLSE for fiber amplifier.

Parameters

  • re_eq (REFiber) -- A fiber rate equation object.

  • alpha (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • gain_order (int) -- The order of the gain coefficients to take into account. (from the Rate Equations resolution)

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • f_R (float) -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • R_0 (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber start.

  • R_L (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber end.

  • nl_index (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The non linear index. Used to calculate the non linear parameter. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\)

  • ATT (bool) -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP (bool) -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM (bool) -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • GS (bool) -- If True, trigger the gain saturation.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber amplifier.

  • dopant (str) -- The doped medium of the fiber amplifier.

op_non_lin(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

Represent the non linear effects of the approximated NLSE.

Parameters

  • waves (Array) -- The wave packet propagating in the fiber.

  • id (int) -- The ID of the considered wave in the wave packet.

  • corr_wave (Optional[Array]) -- Correction wave, use for consistency.

Return type

Array

Returns

The non linear term for the considered wave.

Notes

\[\hat{N} = i \gamma \Big[ (1-f_R) |A|^2 + f_R \mathcal{F}^{-1} \big\{\mathcal{F}\{h_R\}\mathcal{F}\{|A|^2\} \big\}\Big]\]

  • alpha_order (int) -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • FWM (bool) -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • GS (bool) -- If True, trigger the gain saturation.

Represent the non linear effects of the approximated NLSE.

25. Equation: Abstract coupled non-linear Schrodinger equation¶

class optcom.equations.abstract_cnlse.AbstractCNLSE(nbr_fibers, beta, kappa, sigma_cross, c2c_spacing, core_radius, V, n_0, ASYM, COUP, XPM, medium)¶

Coupled non linear Schrodinger equations.

Represent the different effects in the NLSE as well as the interaction of NLSEs propagating along each others. Note that automatic calculation of the coupling coefficients rely on a formula that is only correct for symmetric coupler.

nbr_eqs¶

Number of NLSEs in the CNLSE.

Type

int

Parameters

  • nbr_fibers (int) -- The number of fibers in the coupler.

  • beta (Union[List[List[float]], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\)

  • kappa (Optional[List[List[List[float]]]]) -- The coupling coefficients. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • sigma_cross (List[List[float]]) -- Positive term multiplying the XPM term of the NLSE inbetween the fibers.

  • c2c_spacing (List[List[float]]) -- The center to center distance between two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • core_radius (List[float]) -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • V (List[float]) -- The fiber parameter.

  • n_0 (List[float]) -- The refractive index outside of the waveguides.

  • ASYM (bool) -- If True, trigger the asymmetry effects between cores.

  • COUP (bool) -- If True, trigger the coupling effects between cores.

  • XPM (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber.

29. Equation: Fresnel¶

class optcom.equations.fresnel.Fresnel¶

Fresnel equations.

Represent the Fresnel equations which describe the reflection and transmission of light at the interface of two media.

static irradiance_p_pol(n_1, n_2, theta_i, theta_t=None)¶

Calcul the p-polarization irradiance.

Parameters

  • n_1 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the incident light.

  • n_2 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the transmitted light.

  • theta_i (float) -- The angle of incidence.

  • theta_t (Optional[float]) -- The angle of transmission.

Returns

The p-polarization irradiance.

Notes

\[T_p = 1 - R_p\]
static irradiance_s_pol(n_1, n_2, theta_i, theta_t=None)¶

Calcul the s-polarization irradiance.

Parameters

  • n_1 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the incident light.

  • n_2 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the transmitted light.

  • theta_i (float) -- The angle of incidence.

  • theta_t (Optional[float]) -- The angle of transmission.

Returns

The s-polarization irradiance.

Notes

\[T_s = 1 - R_s\]
static reflectance_p_pol(n_1, n_2, theta_i, theta_t=None)¶

Calcul the s-polarization reflectance.

Parameters

  • n_1 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the incident light.

  • n_2 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the transmitted light.

  • theta_i (float) -- The angle of incidence.

  • theta_t (Optional[float]) -- The angle of transmission.

Returns

The p-polarization reflectance.

Notes

\[R_p = \bigg\lvert \frac{n_1 \cos(\theta_t) - n_2\cos(\theta_i)}{n_1 \cos(\theta_t) + n_2\cos(\theta_i)} \bigg\rvert^2 = \Bigg\lvert\frac{n_1\sqrt{1-\big(\frac{n_1}{n_2} \sin(\theta_i)\big)^2} - n_2\cos(\theta_i)}{n_1\sqrt{1-\big(\frac{n_1}{n_2} \sin(\theta_i)\big)^2} + n_2\cos(\theta_i) } \Bigg\rvert^2\]
static reflectance_s_pol(n_1, n_2, theta_i, theta_t=None)¶

Calcul the s-polarization reflectance.

Parameters

  • n_1 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the incident light.

  • n_2 (Union[float, complex]) -- The refractive index of the medium of the transmitted light.

  • theta_i (float) -- The angle of incidence.

  • theta_t (Optional[float]) -- The angle of transmission.

Returns

The s-polarization reflectance.

Notes

\[R_s = \bigg\lvert \frac{n_1 \cos(\theta_i) - n_2\cos(\theta_t)}{n_1 \cos(\theta_i) + n_2\cos(\theta_t)} \bigg\rvert^2 = \Bigg\lvert \frac{n_1\cos(\theta_i) -n_2\sqrt{1-\big(\frac{n_1}{n_2} \sin(\theta_i)\big)^2}}{n_1\cos(\theta_i) + n_2 \sqrt{1-\big(\frac{n_1}{n_2} \sin(\theta_i)\big)^2}} \Bigg\rvert^2\]

30. Equation: McCumber¶

class optcom.equations.mccumber.McCumber¶

McCumber relations.

Represent McCumber relations which give a relationship between the effective cross-sections of absorption and emission of light in the physics of solid-state lasers. 2

Notes

\[\frac{\sigma_e(\omega)}{\sigma_a(\omega)} \exp\Big[\frac{\hbar \omega}{k_B T}\Big] = \Big(\frac{N_0}{N_1}\Big)_T\]

where \(\Big(\frac{N_0}{N_1}\Big)_T\) is the thermal steady-state ratio of populations at temperature \(T\).

References

2

Miniscalco, W.J. and Quimby, R.S., 1991. General procedure for the analysis of Er 3+ cross sections. Optics letters, 16(4), pp.258-260.

static calc_cross_section_absorption(sigma_e, omega, center_omega, N_0, N_1, T)¶

Calcul the absorption cross section.

Parameters

  • sigma_e -- The emission cross section. \([nm^2]\)

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • N_0 -- The population in ground state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • N_1 -- The population in the excited state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • T -- The temperature. \([K]\)

Returns

Value of the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

Notes

\[\sigma_a(\omega) = \sigma_e(\omega) \exp\Big[\frac{\hbar (\omega -\omega_0}{k_B T}\Big] \Big(\frac{N_0}{N_1}\Big)_T^{-1}\]
static calc_cross_section_emission(sigma_a, omega, center_omega, N_0, N_1, T)¶

Calcul the emission cross section.

Parameters

  • sigma_a -- The absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • N_0 -- The population in ground state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • N_1 -- The population in the excited state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • T -- The temperature. \([K]\)

Returns

Value of the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

Notes

\[\sigma_e(\omega) = \sigma_a(\omega) \exp\Big[-\frac{\hbar (\omega - \omega_0)}{k_B T}\Big] \Big(\frac{N_0}{N_1}\Big)_T\]

31. Equation: Rate Equations for fibers¶

class optcom.equations.re_fiber.REFiber(nbr_eqs)¶

Rate equations for fibers.

32. Equation: Rate Equations with 2 levels for fiber¶

class optcom.equations.re2_fiber.RE2Fiber(sigma_a=None, sigma_e=None, n_core=None, n_clad=None, NA=None, temperature=293.15, tau_meta=840.0, N_T=0.063, core_radius=5.0, clad_radius=62.5, area_doped=None, eta_s=1.26, eta_p=1.41, R_0=0.0008, R_L=0.0008, signal_width=[1.0], medium='sio2', dopant='yt', step_update=False)¶

Rate equations for a 2 levels system in fiber amplifier.

Represent the rate equations of a 2 levels system in steady state with pump power \(P_p\), signal power \(P_s\) and inversion of population \(N_1\) as parameters.

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{alignat}{1} &N_1(z) = \frac{\frac{1}{hcA_c}\Big[\sum^K_{k=1} \Gamma_{s,k}\lambda_k\big[ \sigma_{a,s}(\lambda_k)N_T] P_{s,k}^{\pm}(z) + \sum^L_{l=1} \Gamma_{p,l}\lambda_l\big[\sigma_{a,p}(\lambda_l)N_T \big] P_{p,l}^{\pm}(z)\Big]} {\frac{1}{hcA_c}\Big[\sum^K_{k=1} \Gamma_{s,k}\lambda_k\big[ \sigma_{a,s}(\lambda_k) + \sigma_{e,s}(\lambda_k)\big] P_{s,k}^{\pm}(z) + \sum^L_{l=1} \Gamma_{p,l}\lambda_l \big[\sigma_{a,p}(\lambda_l)+\sigma_{e,p}(\lambda_l) \big] P_{p,l}^{\pm}(z)\Big] - \frac{1}{\tau}}\\ &\frac{\partial P_{s,k}^{\pm}(z)}{\partial z} = \pm \bigg[\Gamma_k\Big[\big(\sigma_{a,s}(\lambda_k) + \sigma_{e,s}(\lambda_k)\big)N_1(z) - \sigma_{a,s}(\lambda_k)N_T\Big] P_{s,k}^\pm (z) - \eta_{s,k} P_{s,k}^\pm (z) + \Gamma_k\sigma_{e,s}(\lambda_k) N_1(z) \frac{2hc^2 \Delta\lambda}{\lambda_k^3} \bigg]\\ &\frac{\partial P_{p,l}^{\pm}(z)}{\partial z} = \pm \bigg[\Gamma_k\Big[\big(\sigma_{a,p}(\lambda_l) + \sigma_{e,p}(\lambda_l)\big)N_1(z) - \sigma_{a,p}(\lambda_l)N_T\Big] P_{p,l}^\pm (z) - \eta_{p,l} P_{p,l}^\pm (z) \bigg] \end{alignat}\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • sigma_a (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The absorption cross sections of the signal and the pump (1<=len(sigma_a)<=2). \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, varibale must be wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • sigma_e (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The emission cross sections of the signal and the pump (1<=len(sigma_a)<=2). \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, varibale must be wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • n_core (Union[float, List[float], None]) -- The refractive index of the core. If the medium is not recognised by Optcom, at least two elements should be provided out of those three: n_core, n_clad, NA.

  • n_clad (Union[float, List[float], None]) -- The refractive index of the cladding. If the medium is not recognised by Optcom, at least two elements should be provided out of those three: n_core, n_clad, NA.

  • NA (Union[float, List[float], None]) -- The numerical aperture. If the medium is not recognised by Optcom, at least two elements should be provided out of those three: n_core, n_clad, NA.

  • temperature (float) -- The temperature of the medium. \([K]\)

  • tau_meta (float) -- The metastable level lifetime. \([\mu s]\)

  • N_T (float) -- The total doping concentration. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • core_radius (float) -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • clad_radius (float) -- The radius of the cladding. \([\mu m]\)

  • area_doped (Optional[float]) -- The doped area. \([\mu m^2]\) If None, will be approximated to the core area.

  • eta_s (float) -- The background signal loss. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • eta_p (float) -- The background pump loss. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • R_0 (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber start.

  • R_L (float) -- The reflectivity at the fiber end.

  • signal_width (List[float]) -- The width of each channel of the signal. \([ps]\)

  • medium (str) -- The main medium of the fiber amplifier.

  • dopant (str) -- The doped medium of the fiber amplifier.

  • step_update (bool) -- If True, update the signal and pump power from the wave arrays at each space step.

absorption(step, order)¶

Return absorption of the pump and signal. Fit calculated absorption and predict main value and derivatives for center omegas.

Parameters

  • step (int) -- The current step of the computation.

  • order (int) -- The order of the taylor series expansion (number of deriv.).

Return type

Array

Returns

The absorption of the fiber at the specified space step. \([km^{-1}]\)

close(domain, *fields)¶

This function is called once after a Stepper ended the computation.

Return type

None

initial_condition(waves, end)¶

Initial conditions for shooting method.

Parameters

  • waves (Array) -- The propagating waves.

  • end (bool) -- If true, boundary counditions at z=L, else at z=0.

Notes

If co-propagating signal and pump:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} P_s^+(z=0) &= R_0 P_s^-(z=0) + P_{s,ref}^+(z=0)\\ P_p^+(z=0) &= R_0 P_p^-(z=0) + P_{p, ref}^+(z=0)\\ P_s^-(z=L) &= R_L P_s^+(z=L)\\ P_p^-(z=L) &= R_L P_s^+(z=L) \end{split}\end{split}\]

If counter-propagating signal and pump:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} P_s^+(z=0) &= R_0 P_s^-(z=0) + P_{s,ref}^+(z=0)\\ P_p^+(z=0) &= R_0 P_p^-(z=0)\\ P_s^-(z=L) &= R_L P_s^+(z=L)\\ P_p^-(z=L) &= R_L P_s^+(z=L) + P_{p, ref}^-(z=0) \end{split}\end{split}\]
Return type

Array

open(domain, *fields)¶

This function is called once before a Stepper began the computation. Pass the time, wavelength and center wavelength to all the effects in the equation.

Return type

None

set(waves, h, z)¶

This function is called before each step of the computation.

Return type

None

update(waves, h, z)¶

This function is called after each step of the computation.

Return type

None

33. Equation: Resonant index change¶

class optcom.equations.resonant_index.ResonantIndex(medium='yb')¶

Compute the resonant index change. 7

References

7

Digonnet, M.J., Sadowski, R.W., Shaw, H.J. and Pantell, R.H., 1997. Experimental evidence for strong UV transition contribution in the resonant nonlinearity of doped fibers. Journal of lightwave technology, 15(2), pp.299-303.

Parameters

medium (str) -- The medium in which the wave propagates.

calc_Q(n_0)¶

Compute the Q factor.

Parameters

n_0 -- The refractive index.

Returns

The Q factor. \([ps^{-1} nm^{2}]\)

Notes

\[Q = \frac{e^2 (n_0^2+2)^2}{72 n_0 m \epsilon_0 c}\]
lorentzian_lineshape(lambda_s, Lambda, lambda_bw)¶

Compute the lorentzian lineshape.

Parameters

  • lambda_s -- The center wavelength of the wave signal. \([nm]\)

  • Lambda -- The reference wavelength. \([nm]\) (depends on the material)

  • lambda_bw -- The wavelength bandwidth. \([nm]\)

Returns

The lorentzian lineshape. \([ps]\)

Notes

\[g'_{ij}(\lambda_s) = \frac{1}{\pi c} \frac{ \frac{1}{\lambda_{ij}} \Big(\frac{1} {\lambda_{ij}^2}-\frac{1}{\lambda_{s}^2}\Big)} {\Big(\frac{1}{\lambda_{ij}^2} -\frac{1}{\lambda_{s}^2}\Big) + \Big(\frac{\Delta\lambda_{ij}} {\lambda_s \lambda_{ij}^2}\Big)}\]
n(omega, n_0, N_1)¶

Compute the resonant index change.

Parameters

omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

Returns

The refractive index change.

Notes

\[\Delta n = Q N_1 S\]

where:

\[S = -f_{12}\lambda_{12}g'_{12}(\lambda_s) \big(1 + \frac{g_1}{g_2}\big) - \sum_{j>2} f_{1j} \lambda_{1j}g'_{1j}(\lambda_s) + \sum_{j>2} f_{2j}\lambda_{2j}g'_{2j}(\lambda_s)\]

34. Equation: Sellmeier¶

class optcom.equations.sellmeier.Sellmeier(medium='sio2', Bs=None, Cs=None)¶

Sellmeier equations.

Represent the Sellmeier equations which are empirical relationship between refractive index and wavelength for a specific medium. 1

References

1

Malitson, I.H., 1965. Interspecimen comparison of the refractive index of fused silica. Josa, 55(10), pp.1205-1209.

Parameters

  • medium (str) -- The medium in which the wave propagates.

  • Bs (Optional[List[float]]) -- B coefficients.

  • Cs (Optional[List[float]]) -- C coefficients.

n(omega)¶

Compute the Sellmeier equations.

Parameters

omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

Returns

The refractive index.

Notes

\[n^2(\lambda) = 1 + \sum_i B_i \frac{\lambda^2}{\lambda^2 - C_i}\]

Optcom
